We could call it propaganda, but it is really about putting a thought into some ones head that a given situation or person should be seen in a certain way. Politicians and pundits use the same buzz words over and over. How many times have we heard "Bush Lied" or "Liberals are anti -American?" After a while people begin to believe it so it becomes a "fact" in their mind. Sometimes it doesn't have to be repeated very often. It could be as simple as starting a rumor that so and so is racist. You perceive what he does from the perspective of racism and look for a way to support the rumor. How much influence do you think the power of suggestion has on how we judge people and situations?

Probably more than you suspect. Take a look at Bush's "tax relief" package from a little while ago. All it was was tax cuts for rich people. However, Bush and every repubican used the phrase "tax relief" whenever they talked about it. It got to the point where even those opposed to the package called it "Bush's tax relief program". Now, eveyone knows that relief is good, that's the definition. So you ended up with people on camera arguing against relief. The facts, of course, clearly showed that the package was idiotic. However, people don't often use facts to make up their minds, they use their guts. And their guts told them that relief is good, and anyone who is against relief must be wrong. And so the program gained popular support, despite the fact that almost no one benefited from it, and our children will be paying off the accumulating debt for years. It's all in how you phrase your stance.
